question_text:
Devon runs a day care centre. Of the 18 children at the day care centre, 8 of them are two-year-olds. What is the probability that a randomly selected child will be a two-year-old?

Write your answer as a fraction or whole number.

P(two-year-old) = _
solution: The probability is the number of favourable outcomes out of the number of possible outcomes.

Write the probability as a fraction in simplest form.
P(two-year-old) = $\frac{\text{two-year-olds}}{\text{total}}=\frac{8}{18}=\frac{4}{9}$
P(two-year-old) = $\frac{4}{9}$

question_text:
You pick a card at random. What is P(5)?

Write your answer as a percentage. _
backend_description: The image shows four pink cards placed in a row, each with a white number. The cards display the numbers 2, 3, 4, and 5 from left to right.
solution: The probability is the number of favourable outcomes out of the number of possible outcomes.

There are 4 cards, numbered 2, 3, 4 and 5.
$P(5) = \frac{1}{4}$

Write your answer as a decimal. Then convert your answer to a percentage.
$\frac{1}{4}=0.25=25\%$

question_text:
You flip a coin. What is P(heads)?

Write your answer as a fraction or whole number. _
solution: Flipping a coin has two possibilities: heads or tails.
P(heads) = $\frac{1}{2}$.

question_text:

P(set-piece drill) = _
solution: The probability is the number of favourable outcomes out of the number of possible outcomes.

Write the probability as a fraction in simplest form.
P(set-piece drill) = $\frac{\text{set-piece drills}}{\text{total}}=\frac{16}{25}=\frac{16}{25}$
P(set-piece drill) = $\frac{16}{25}$

P(overtime game) = $\frac{3}{4}$

question_text:
